channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jeffrey Fowle, American Held by North Korea, Is Released
item.description: The Ohio man was let go after nearly six months of captivity, officials said. The United States is still working on freeing two others.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: For Chinese, a Remarkable Sight: Freewheeling Debate on Democracy
item.description: After more than three weeks of protests, the meeting resembled less a negotiating session than a high school debate.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters watched a live broadcast of a meeting between student leaders and government officials in the Admiralty district of Hong Kong on Tuesday. Carrie Lam, the second-highest ranking official in Hong Kong, is seen on the screen at right.

item.title: World Briefing: Britain Extradites Terrorism Suspect to U.S.
item.description: Haroon Aswat, a Briton, is wanted in the United States on accusations that he conspired in 1999 to set up a terrorist training camp in Oregon.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Submarine Search Near Stockholm Reminiscent of a Cold War Thriller
item.description: Sweden launched a search team of 200 personnel aboard ships, helicopters and minesweepers to scour the Baltic Sea in search of an unidentified foreign vessel.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A Swedish minesweeper searched for evidence of "foreign underwater activity" in the Stockholm archipelago on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Britain, Child Sex Abuse Defies Easy Stereotypes
item.description: High-profile revelations of child sexual abuse have shown the risks of ascribing blame according to class or race.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Gough Whitlam, Former Australian Premier Who Showed Prescience With China, Dies at 98
item.description: Mr. Whitlam, who introduced free university education and national health care as prime minister, is credited for his early recognition of China’s government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Spanish Nurse Infected With Ebola Is Declared Free of Disease
item.description: Tests for the disease done on María Teresa Romero Ramos have twice come back negative, hospital officials said.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Indian Politician Pledges Payments to Families of Supporters Who Died in Distress for Her
item.description: The party of Jayalalithaa Jayaram, the former chief minister of Tamil Nadu, says 193 followers have died or committed suicide since she was imprisoned for corruption.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Nuclear Deal, Now or Never
item.description: Voting cycles in America and Iran leave only a small window of opportunity — starting right after Election Day.
item.dc:creator: By VALI R. NASR

item.title: Paris Journal: The Secret Is Out on a Cherished Underground Haven
item.description: A secretive community of street artists, history buffs and other Parisians regularly prowl a network of abandoned tunnels and chambers.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: An artist known as Nobad, center, was joined by friends in a gallery of the Paris catacombs. Regulars try not to reveal the tunnel entrances to outsiders.

item.title: Museum of the History of Polish Jews in Warsaw to Unveil Core Exhibition
item.description: An exhibition in Warsaw, occupying eight sprawling galleries, traces the history of Jews from their first appearance in Poland in the Middle Ages to the present day.
item.category: Museum of the History of Polish Jews
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The core exhibition of the Museum of the History of Polish Jews will be unveiled on Oct. 28.

item.title: Lens Blog: Revisiting Unhealed Wounds in Chechnya
item.description: Stanley Greene returned to Chechnya to document the aftermath of the 1993 conflict, and his photographs were gathered into a book, “Open Wound.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: On his visit to Chechnya, Mr. Greene found posters of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, in many places. The National Theater, Grozny, Chechnya. 2013.

item.title: World Briefing: Northern Ireland Orders Inquiry Into Rape Charges Against I.R.A. Member
item.description: The investigation will look at prosecutors’ handling of allegations by a woman that she was raped by a senior I.R.A. member, then interrogated in “kangaroo courts.”
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Ashraf Ghani Races to Make His Mark on Presidency in Afghanistan
item.description: As President Ashraf Ghani breaks from the courtly style of his predecessor, Hamid Karzai, his desire to move fast may put off others in his government.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani earlier this month. There is a concern among some in Afghanistan about his temperament, Western style and didactic approach.

item.title: Sudan's Bashir Chosen by Ruling Party as Candidate for 2015 Elections
item.description: Sudan's ruling party chose President Omar Hassan al-Bashir on Tuesday as its candidate for next year's presidential vote, making it almost certain that he will not step aside but extend his rule after 25 years in power.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: For E.U. Climate Meeting, Deep Divisions and High Stakes
item.description: Curbing emissions has long been a popular cause in the European Union. But leaders have to agree on how to generate and distribute energy.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Canadian Soldier, Run Down in What Officials Call Act of Terror, Dies
item.description: Patrice Vincent, a 53-year-old warrant officer, was struck by a car in Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, near Montreal. A second member of the military sustained less serious injuries.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Asia Society Names Former Australian Prime Minister as Research Institute Head
item.description: Kevin Rudd will lead the Asia Society Policy Institute, a new organization that specializes in Asian issues and policy making.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Conor Ashleigh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Rudd, the former prime minister of Australia, in 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Love Blooms Amid the Umbrellas in Hong Kong
item.description: The barricaded areas in the financial district have served as a backdrop for wedding and graduation photos, as young Hong Kongers intertwine their personal lives with the historical significance of the protests.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A couple posed for wedding photographs against a backdrop of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong on Oct. 1.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Brazilians Are Shocked, Shocked at Corruption!
item.description: We have the ability to be outraged by corner-cutting, while engaging in our own petty versions of it.
item.dc:creator: By ANTONIO PRATA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Russia Today, Argentina Tomorrow
item.description: Latin America's populist leaders are degrading independent journalism.
item.dc:creator: By FABIÁN BOSOER and FEDERICO FINCHELSTEIN

item.title: For Pistorius, Five-Year Term May Mean Move To House Arrest
item.description: The South African track star, who was found guilty of culpable homicide in the killing of his girlfriend, was also given a suspended three-year term on separate firearms charges.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius held the hands of family members after being sentenced to five years in prison on Tuesday.

item.title: Christophe de Margerie, C.E.O. of Total, French Oil Giant, Dies in Accident
item.description: Mr. de Margerie was killed when his business jet collided with a snowplow on the runway of Vnukovo International Airport in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Christophe de Margerie became chief executive of Total in 2007.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rare Night Scenes of Mother Panda and Cub Filmed in the Wild
item.description: Chinese news media say this is the first time an infrared camera has been used to film a panda mother and cub at night.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Group Details Abuse in ‘Black Jails’
item.description: As China’s Communist Party meets to discuss the rule of law and the United Nations hears China’s national report on women’s rights, a rights group publishes a report documenting routine physical and sexual abuse of women in unofficial jails.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
